summary: Build a lifestyle website for adult plushie enthusiasts named "Plushie Haven."
architectural_notes: Visual theme direction updated: prioritize an ‘adorable’ aesthetic with a pink + baby blue palette (supersedes prior guidance to avoid blue/purple-dominant palettes).
Events direction updated: replace static/seeded events with user-submitted events (users can add events).

Theme update: use exact palette—backgrounds #FFFFFF or #FDFDFD; primary accents/baby blue #89CFF0 or #A2DFFE (prominent on buttons/borders/cards/highlights); tertiary accents/pink #FFB6C1 or #FFD1DC (used sparingly); text #4A90E2 or #333333; rounded corners + gentle shadows; avoid dark/edgy tones; apply site-wide consistently.
Header branding: include a cute pastel teddy bear with a bow in the header, matching the baby blue + pink palette.
UI polish: do not leave unexplained placeholder shapes (e.g., empty circle/square). Replace with intended branding/icons or remove from the layout.
Home page hero/title area: replace the small circular placeholder to the left of the large blue “Plushie Haven” text (above the tagline paragraph) with the teddy bear logo (do not leave it empty).

Community Board moderation direction: designate the currently authenticated Internet Identity principal as the admin (for now); admins can edit/delete any post, while regular users can delete only their own posts.

Profiles direction: build both individual profile pages and a public profile directory; profiles are publicly viewable but only editable when logged in; users are hidden from the directory by default unless they opt in (and can opt out). Profile fields include avatar, display name, bio, links, and plushie collection images (and future optional fields).
Header account display: when signed in, show the user’s Profile display name in the header (replacing the person icon); when signed out, show the existing Sign In UI.
Coloring section decision updated: remove the entire Coloring page/section from the site (remove the /coloring route and its UI).
known_issues: Random empty circle and square placeholders appear in the UI; user requested to fill them with intended content or remove them.
Home page hero image next to the “Plushie Haven” title (alt text “A cozy collection of beloved plushies”) is not displaying for the user (no image shown).

existing_features.title: Create the core frontend app for an adult plushie lover lifestyle website named “Plushie Haven”, including a responsive layout with header navigation, footer, and the following pages/sections with English user-facing text: Home (hero + intro), Articles/Guides (list + detail), Gallery (image grid), Community Board (posts list + create post), Events (upcoming list), About, and Contact (non-email form UI with copy-to-clipboard or mailto link).

Implement a consistent, distinctive visual theme for Plushie Haven (colors, typography, spacing, and UI styling) suitable for an adult lifestyle community; avoid a blue/purple-dominant palette. Apply the theme consistently across all pages and components.
Add an age confirmation gate for adult audiences: on first visit, require the user to confirm they are 18+ to enter Plushie Haven, with a persistent “confirmed” state stored locally in the browser.
Integrate Internet Identity sign-in on the frontend and require authentication for creating Community Board posts; unauthenticated users can browse posts but must sign in to post.

Seed the Articles/Guides and Events sections with curated static content appropriate for adult plushie enthusiasts (e.g., care tips, collecting, display ideas, travel/events etiquette), ensuring content remains safe and non-explicit.

Generate and include required static brand images for Plushie Haven, store them in frontend/public/assets/generated, and use them in the UI (e.g., logo in header, hero image on home, subtle background pattern).

Update the site-wide visual theme to an adorable pink + baby blue palette, applied consistently across all pages and components (including light/dark mode variables), while maintaining readable contrast for text and UI states (buttons, borders, muted backgrounds, focus rings).
Replace the current seeded Events section with a user-submitted Events feature: users can browse all events, and authenticated users can create new events from the Events page UI.

Update the frontend to support the new Events backend data flow: add React Query hooks for listing and creating events, and rebuild the Events page UI to include a user-submitted events list and a create-event form (mirroring the Community Board auth/validation patterns).

Refresh the Gallery section to use a more plushie-forward scheme: update gallery items to use dedicated plushie images (not the logo/hero/pattern reused repeatedly), and update the Gallery presentation to match the new adorable aesthetic.
Update the Community Board UI to allow authenticated users to attach an image to a new post, preview it before posting, and display attached images in the posts list.

Update the frontend backend-integration layer (React Query hooks and generated/typed backend bindings) so Community Board post creation can send an optional image attachment and post listing can consume and render image attachment data.

Update the header brand area so the small image next to the site title is a clearly visible, cute logo mark (e.g., a bear), matching the user’s request for the circular placeholder area near “Sign In” / “Plushie Haven”. Keep the existing header layout and link-to-home behavior, but adjust styling so the logo reads well at small sizes (including making it circular if appropriate).

Ensure the Home page hero area around the “Plushie Haven” headline and the tagline/description includes a prominent image so the section does not look empty. Use a plushie-themed image (either the site logo artwork or a plushie image) and ensure it renders well responsively (desktop and mobile).

Add an additional image-forward section to the Home page (frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx) to make the page feel more visually rich beyond the existing hero image. The section must display multiple plushie-themed images with short captions, be fully responsive (mobile through desktop), and match the existing adorable site aesthetic.

Redesign the site-wide theme tokens to match the user-specified exact palette: primary backgrounds must be pure white (#FFFFFF) or very light off-white (#FDFDFD); baby blue (#89CFF0 or #A2DFFE) must be the prominent accent for headers, buttons, borders, card backgrounds, and highlights; pastel pink (#FFB6C1 or #FFD1DC) must be used sparingly for warmth (e.g., links, small icons, subtle highlights/gradients); main text must use dark baby blue (#4A90E2) or soft charcoal (#333333) for readability. Apply consistently across all pages and components.

Update global component styling to emphasize a cute, rounded plushie-cozy look site-wide: soft corners (rounded shapes) and gentle shadows, with no harsh outlines. Ensure this styling is applied consistently to interactive controls (buttons, inputs, sheets/dialogs), cards, and navigation elements.

Add a cute pastel teddy bear with a bow (matching the baby blue + pastel pink palette) to the header brand mark and use it in the existing circular logo area without changing the header layout or home-link behavior.

Identify where the UI renders the “random empty circle and square” placeholder shapes, and remove them or replace them with meaningful content so there are no unexplained empty geometric placeholders visible anywhere in the layout.

Ensure the Home page hero image asset referenced by `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx` at `/assets/generated/plushie-haven-hero.dim_1600x900.png` exists in `frontend/public/assets/generated` and is served correctly in the deployed build so the hero image renders on the Home page.

Add a resilient fallback for the Home page hero image in `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx` so that if the hero image fails to load (e.g., missing asset or transient failure), the UI displays a visually appropriate fallback (e.g., the site logo in a styled container) instead of showing no image.

On the Home page hero section, replace the circular image shown immediately to the left of the blue “Plushie Haven” title text (above the tagline paragraph) with the same teddy bear-with-bow logo mark used in the header. Use the existing static asset path `/assets/generated/plushie-haven-teddy-bow-mark.dim_512x512.png`, keep the circle styling, and update the image alt text to describe the teddy bear logo clearly.

Update the frontend-backend integration (typed bindings + React Query hooks) to support: (1) checking admin status, (2) claiming admin (one-time), (3) deleting posts, and (4) editing posts; ensure the posts list refreshes automatically after successful edit/delete operations.

Update the Community Board UI to add per-post controls: show a Delete action for (a) admins on all posts and (b) authenticated non-admin authors on their own posts; show an Edit action for admins on all posts. Provide an inline or modal edit experience that lets an admin update the post title and message, with cancel/save actions and appropriate loading/disabled states. Add a confirmation step before deletion.

Update the generated/typed frontend backend bindings and React Query hooks to support: fetching the public profile directory, fetching a profile by principal, fetching the signed-in user’s own profile for editing, and saving the signed-in user’s profile. Ensure queries invalidate/refresh appropriately after a successful save.

Add a new Profiles section to the frontend including: (1) a public profile directory page that shows only opted-in profiles, and (2) an individual profile page that can be visited publicly when opted-in. Include clear English empty states when no profiles are listed or when a profile is not available to the viewer.

Implement authenticated profile editing: on the individual profile page, if the viewer is the profile owner (same Internet Identity principal), show an Edit Profile UI that allows updating all profile fields (avatar, display name, bio, links, plushie collection images) and toggling directory opt-in/out. Editing must require login; unauthenticated users must not see editing controls.
Add navigation access to the new Profiles section in the existing site navigation without changing unrelated layout structure or modifying immutable frontend paths.

Update the header authentication control so that when a user is signed in, the dropdown trigger displays the user’s chosen username (their Profile display name) instead of the person/user icon and short principal text.

Fetch and keep the signed-in user’s profile display name up-to-date in the header auth control by using the existing profile query for the caller’s profile; ensure the header label updates automatically after the user saves/changes their profile display name (without a full page reload).

Update the generated frontend backend bindings/types and add React Query hooks to call the new follow + like canister methods, following existing patterns in `frontend/src/hooks/useQueries.ts` and `frontend/src/hooks/useProfileQueries.ts` (query invalidation after successful mutations must refresh relevant counts/states).

Add post-like UI to the Community Board (`frontend/src/pages/CommunityBoardPage.tsx`): render a Like button and like count on each post in the main list. If the user is not signed in, clicking Like must show an English error message prompting sign-in; if signed in, clicking toggles like/unlike and updates the count. Use clear, non-technical English text labels.

Implement a usable Profiles follow experience: (1) add an individual profile route (e.g. `/profiles/$principal`) wired into `frontend/src/App.tsx`, (2) update the Profiles directory (`frontend/src/pages/ProfilesDirectoryPage.tsx`) so “View Profile” is enabled and navigates to the individual profile page, and (3) on the individual profile page, render Follow/Unfollow and Profile Like/Unlike controls with follower/following counts and profile like count. Require sign-in for follow/like actions and show English sign-in prompts when unauthenticated users attempt actions.

Update the generated frontend backend bindings/types and add React Query hooks in `frontend/src/hooks/useQueries.ts` for: (1) listing comments for a post, (2) creating a comment for a post, and (3) fetching comment counts per post, including appropriate query invalidation after successful comment creation.

Update `frontend/src/pages/CommunityBoardPage.tsx` to display comment counts for each post in the posts list and provide an in-place comments UI per post that allows browsing comments and (when authenticated) adding a new comment.

Update the seeded site content to include clothing items (onesies, leotards, oversized sweaters) and accessories (pacifiers, lock-and-key necklaces, thigh-high socks) as part of Plushie Haven’s lifestyle content, using safe, non-explicit, English user-facing text.
Add a clear UI call-to-action to download the Coloring Book PDF (including a prominent button/link) on an existing page, using English user-facing text and matching the current Plushie Haven styling.

Make the Home page Coloring Book download call-to-action resilient when the PDF is missing or fails to load: if `/assets/coloring-book.pdf` cannot be reached, disable the download button and show a clear English message explaining the download is temporarily unavailable.

Make the static-asset availability check compatible with production hosting by updating `frontend/src/hooks/useStaticAssetAvailability.ts` to not rely solely on an HTTP `HEAD` request (which may be unsupported), and to fall back to a lightweight `GET` check when needed.

Update the Home page download CTA in `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx` so that when the PDF is available the download action uses a standard link behavior (e.g., an `<a href="/assets/coloring-book.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">` around the button) rather than only `window.open`, and show a clear English error message if a user attempts to download but the file cannot be reached.

Make the Home page Coloring Book PDF download work reliably in production at the exact URL `/assets/coloring-book.pdf`, ensuring the asset is included in the deployed frontend static files and can be fetched successfully by the browser.

Update `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx` so the download click verification does not rely solely on an HTTP `HEAD` request (which may be blocked/unsupported in some hosting setups); it must use a fallback strategy compatible with production hosting (e.g., attempt `HEAD`, then fall back to a lightweight `GET` check) before preventing navigation and showing an error.

Add a clear, user-facing failure mode on the Home page download CTA when the availability state is unknown or inconsistent (e.g., the initial availability check indicates available but the click-time check fails), using concise English text and keeping the existing Plushie Haven styling.

Ensure the Coloring Book PDF static asset is present in the deployed frontend and is served successfully at the exact URL `/assets/coloring-book.pdf` (the same URL used by the Home page download link), so clicking the download button no longer opens a blank white “Not Found” page.

Add a simple developer-facing verification step in the codebase (documentation or a lightweight script) that checks the deployed/static build includes `/assets/coloring-book.pdf`, to prevent regressions where the PDF is missing from production builds.

Remove the Coloring Book feature from the frontend Home page by deleting the entire "Coloring Book Download Section" UI (including its card, button/link, availability/loading states, and error alerts) from `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx`, so the Home page no longer displays any coloring-book-related call-to-action or messaging.

Remove all Home page code that supports the Coloring Book download flow, including: imports used only for the Coloring Book section (e.g., `Download`, `AlertCircle`, `Alert`, `AlertDescription`), the `useStaticAssetAvailability('/assets/coloring-book.pdf')` usage, download-click verification logic that checks `/assets/coloring-book.pdf`, and any related React state (e.g., `downloadError`). Ensure `frontend/src/pages/HomePage.tsx` has no remaining references to `/assets/coloring-book.pdf`.

Remove any remaining Coloring Book references elsewhere in the frontend (text labels, links, asset-path checks, or documentation/comments) so the application contains no user-facing Coloring Book feature entry points.

Create a new Coloring section/page in the frontend that can be visited at a dedicated route (e.g. `/coloring`) and presents a single coloring page based on the user-uploaded image `icoloring-9sd9.png`, with clear English headings and descriptive helper text that match the existing Plushie Haven styling.
Add navigation access to the new Coloring section in the existing site navigation so users can reach it from both desktop and mobile menus.

Add a downloadable, one-page PDF generated from the uploaded image `icoloring-9sd9.png` as a static frontend asset, and provide a prominent Download button/link on the Coloring page that downloads/opens the PDF in a new tab.

Make the Coloring page download experience resilient: check availability of the PDF static asset and disable the Download control with a clear English message when the PDF is missing or cannot be reached, using the existing `useStaticAssetAvailability` hook.
Store the uploaded image `icoloring-9sd9.png` as a static frontend asset and reference it from the Coloring page preview using a stable URL path.

Remove the PDF download button/feature from the Coloring page (`frontend/src/pages/ColoringPage.tsx`) while keeping the Coloring page itself and the existing PDF asset in the project. This includes removing the download availability check UI states, the Download button/link, and any related imports/constants/state that are only used to support downloading.

Update the user-facing text on the Coloring page (`frontend/src/pages/ColoringPage.tsx`) so it no longer instructs the user to download the coloring page (since the download feature is being removed), while keeping the text in clear, friendly English that matches the existing Plushie Haven style.

Remove the Coloring page route from the app router so `/coloring` is no longer a valid page, including removing the `ColoringPage` import, the `coloringRoute` definition, and the `coloringRoute` entry in the `routeTree` in `frontend/src/App.tsx`.

Remove the Coloring link from the site navigation so users cannot navigate to `/coloring` from either desktop or mobile menus by deleting the `/coloring` entry from `navLinks` in `frontend/src/components/Nav.tsx`.
Delete the Coloring page implementation file `frontend/src/pages/ColoringPage.tsx` and ensure no remaining frontend code imports or references it.

Remove Coloring-related static assets from the frontend project (delete the uploaded Coloring PNG and any associated Coloring PDF/assets) so no Coloring assets remain in the shipped frontend static files.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create the "Plushie Haven" lifestyle website for adult plushie lovers, featuring plushie-themed content and community elements.

Implement backend support for the Community Board: authenticated users can create, list, and view posts. Each post stores: id, author principal, author display name (optional), title, body, createdAt timestamp. Provide canister methods for createPost and listPosts (and getPost by id if needed for the UI).
Update the site’s visual theme to be more adorable, using a pink + baby blue color palette across the UI.
Change Events from a static upcoming list to a user-submitted events feature (users can add their own events; remove the pre-seeded Events section/content).
Update the Gallery section to use a more plushie-forward scheme (more plushie imagery/content and presentation aligned with the new adorable aesthetic).

Implement backend canister support for user-submitted Events, similar to Community Board posts: add an Event type and canister methods to create and list events (and a get-by-id method if needed for the UI).
Add image upload support in the Community Board so users can attach/upload images to their posts (UI + storage/back-end as needed).

Extend the Community Board Post data model and canister API to support an optional single image attachment per post, including storing the image bytes and content type with the post so it can be displayed later.
Add/insert a visible logo graphic in the small circular placeholder area near the site title/sign-in in the header on the homepage (e.g., cute bear logo).
Add a hero/feature image on the homepage near the "Plushie Haven, a cozy collection of beloved plushies" text to reduce empty space (use either a plushie image or the logo).
Add additional plushie-themed images to the Home page (beyond the existing hero) to make the page feel more visually rich.

Redesign the site-wide color scheme to match the user-specified exact palette (white/off-white backgrounds, baby blue #89CFF0/#A2DFFE as prominent accents, pastel pink #FFB6C1/#FFD1DC used sparingly, main text #4A90E2 or #333333), with consistently cute/rounded UI styling and no dark/edgy tones.
Update the header brand/logo graphic to a cute pastel teddy bear with a bow that matches the baby blue + pink palette.

Remove or replace the random empty placeholder UI shapes (empty circle and square) by filling them with the intended icons/branding (e.g., teddy bear logo) or removing them entirely so no unexplained shapes remain in the layout.

Add Community Board post deletion and editing with admin controls: make the currently authenticated Internet Identity principal the admin (for now); admins can edit/delete any post; regular users can delete their own posts.

Implement admin role assignment in the backend such that the currently authenticated Internet Identity principal can become the admin (for now) without requiring a hard-coded principal ID. Provide a canister method that allows claiming admin only when no admin has been set yet, and provide a canister method for the frontend to determine whether the current caller is an admin.

Add backend support for deleting Community Board posts with authorization rules: admins can delete any post; non-admin authenticated users can delete only their own posts; anonymous users cannot delete posts.

Add backend support for editing Community Board posts as an admin tool: admins can edit any post’s title/body (and optionally authorName), while non-admin users cannot edit posts unless explicitly allowed (do not allow regular-user editing unless needed by the UI). Editing must not change the post id, author principal, or createdAt timestamp.

Add user Profiles: individual user profile pages plus a public profile directory. Profiles include avatar, display name, bio, links, and plushie collection images (and future optional fields). Profiles are publicly viewable; editing requires login. Users are hidden from the public directory by default unless they opt in (and can opt out).

Extend the backend user profile model to support a full profile with the following fields: avatar image (bytes + content type), display name, bio, links, plushie collection images (multiple images, each bytes + content type), and a public directory opt-in flag. Keep fields optional where appropriate to support future optional fields without breaking callers.

Update backend authorization rules for profiles to match: profiles are publicly viewable when the profile owner has opted into the public directory; otherwise, viewing a profile is restricted to the owner and admins. Editing a profile (saving) requires the caller to be authenticated.

Add backend canister methods to support a public profile directory and profile CRUD flows needed by the UI: (1) get the caller’s profile (for editing), (2) get a profile by principal with the access rules described, (3) save/update the caller’s profile, and (4) list directory profiles (only those opted in).
Replace the header’s person/user icon with the signed-in user’s chosen username (Profile display name). When logged out, keep showing “Sign In” (or equivalent).
Expand the Community Board to support comments on posts (including text and optional image attachments), with comment counts shown on the posts list and within a post detail view.
Add likes and emoji reactions to Community Board posts (one like per user plus reactions), showing counts on the posts list and within a post detail view.
Add follow functionality as a community feature (users can follow other user profiles), with follow counts and an optional “Following” feed/filter experience.

Extend the Motoko backend (single main actor in `backend/main.mo`) to support following between user principals (profile follows), including storing follow relationships and exposing canister methods to: (1) follow a target user principal, (2) unfollow a target user principal, (3) check whether the caller follows a target user principal, and (4) fetch follow counts for a target user principal (followers count and following count). Enforce that only authenticated users can follow/unfollow and that users cannot follow themselves.

Extend the Motoko backend (in `backend/main.mo`) to support likes with one-like-per-user semantics for: (a) Community Board posts and (b) user profiles. Add canister methods to like/unlike a post by post id, query whether the caller has liked a post, and fetch like counts; and likewise like/unlike a profile by principal, query whether the caller has liked a profile, and fetch profile like counts. Enforce that only authenticated users can like/unlike.
Extend the Motoko backend in `backend/main.mo` to support comments on Community Board posts, including a new `Comment` data type and canister methods to create and list comments for a given post.
Add backend query support for displaying comment counts per post without requiring the UI to fetch full comment lists for every post in the feed.
Add/expand site content to include clothing items (onesies, leotards, oversized sweaters) and accessories (pacifiers, lock-and-key necklaces, thigh-high socks).
Remove any remaining Coloring-related user-facing text, links, or references anywhere else in the frontend so there are no entry points or mentions of a Coloring feature in the UI.
